title: Analytic Geometry, Parametric & Polar
description: Conic sections (parabolas, ellipses, hyperbolas) in standard and general form with geometric properties; parametric equations and their graphs; polar coordinates and curves including conversions between rectangular and polar forms.
goals: Analyze parabolas: vertex, focus, directrix, axis of symmetry, equation from geometric properties.
Analyze ellipses: center, vertices, co-vertices, foci, eccentricity, equation from geometric properties.
Analyze hyperbolas: center, vertices, foci, asymptotes, eccentricity, equation from geometric properties.
Write and interpret parametric equations; eliminate the parameter; graph parametric curves.
Convert between polar and rectangular coordinates; plot polar coordinates.
Graph polar curves (circles, roses, limaçons, cardioids, lemniscates) and convert equations between forms.
instructionalStrategy: Gradual release model; AI-led instruction using scaffold as scope
Geometric visualization emphasized — relate algebra to shape properties
Spiral prior skills: completing the square, trig identities, graphing transformations

scaffold.title: Parabolas: Vertex, Focus, Directrix
scaffold.content: A parabola is the set of points equidistant from a fixed point (focus) and a fixed line (directrix). Standard forms center at vertex (h, k).
keyPoints: Vertical axis: (x-h)² = 4p(y-k). Focus: (h, k+p). Directrix: y = k-p.
Horizontal axis: (y-k)² = 4p(x-h). Focus: (h+p, k). Directrix: x = h-p.
p > 0: opens up/right. p < 0: opens down/left.
Focal length |p| = distance from vertex to focus = distance from vertex to directrix.
Latus rectum length = |4p| (width of parabola through focus).
From general form Ax² + Bx + Cy + D = 0: complete the square.

examples.problem: Find the vertex, focus, directrix, and axis of symmetry of (x-3)² = -8(y+1).
examples.solution: Standard form (x-h)²=4p(y-k): h=3, k=-1, 4p=-8 → p=-2. Vertex: (3,-1). Focus: (3, -1+(-2)) = (3,-3). Directrix: y = -1-(-2) = y = 1. Axis of symmetry: x = 3. Opens downward (p < 0).

examples.problem: Write the equation of a parabola with focus (2, 5) and directrix y = 1.
examples.solution: Vertex is midpoint between focus and directrix: (2, (5+1)/2) = (2, 3). p = 5-3 = 2 (opens up). Equation: (x-2)² = 4(2)(y-3) = 8(y-3).

examples.problem: Convert to standard form and find all features: x² + 6x + 4y + 1 = 0.
examples.solution: Complete the square: (x²+6x+9) + 4y + 1 - 9 = 0 → (x+3)² = -4y + 8 = -4(y-2). Standard form: (x+3)² = -4(y-2). 4p=-4 → p=-1. Vertex: (-3,2). Focus: (-3, 2+(-1)) = (-3,1). Directrix: y = 2-(-1) = 3. Opens down.

scaffold.title: Ellipses: Center, Vertices, Foci
scaffold.content: An ellipse is the set of points where the sum of distances to two foci is constant. Key relationship: c² = a² - b² where a > b.
keyPoints: Horizontal major axis: (x-h)²/a² + (y-k)²/b² = 1, a > b
Vertical major axis: (x-h)²/b² + (y-k)²/a² = 1, a > b
Center: (h,k). Vertices: (h±a, k) or (h, k±a). Co-vertices: (h±b, k) or (h, k±b)
Foci: distance c from center along major axis. c² = a² - b²
Eccentricity: e = c/a, 0 < e < 1. Closer to 0 → more circular
From general form: complete the square for both x and y

examples.problem: For (x-1)²/25 + (y+2)²/16 = 1, find center, vertices, co-vertices, foci, and eccentricity.
examples.solution: Center: (1,-2). a²=25 → a=5, b²=16 → b=4. Horizontal major axis. Vertices: (1±5,-2) = (-4,-2) and (6,-2). Co-vertices: (1,-2±4) = (1,-6) and (1,2). c² = 25-16 = 9 → c=3. Foci: (1±3,-2) = (-2,-2) and (4,-2). Eccentricity: e = 3/5 = 0.6.

examples.problem: Write the equation of an ellipse with foci at (0,±4) and vertices at (0,±5).
examples.solution: Vertical major axis, center (0,0). a=5 (vertices), c=4 (foci). b² = a²-c² = 25-16 = 9 → b=3. Equation: x²/9 + y²/25 = 1.

Group: 4(x²-4x) + 9(y²+6y) = -61. Complete squares: 4(x²-4x+4) + 9(y²+6y+9) = -61+16+81 = 36. 4(x-2)²+9(y+3)²=36. Divide by 36: (x-2)²/9+(y+3)²/4=1. Center (2,-3), a=3, b=2, horizontal major axis. c²=9-4=5, c=√5. Foci: (2±√5,-3).

scaffold.title: Hyperbolas: Center, Vertices, Asymptotes
scaffold.content: A hyperbola is the set of points where the absolute difference of distances to two foci is constant. Key relationship: c² = a² + b².
keyPoints: Horizontal transverse: (x-h)²/a² - (y-k)²/b² = 1. Opens left/right.
Vertical transverse: (y-k)²/a² - (x-h)²/b² = 1. Opens up/down.
Vertices: (h±a, k) or (h, k±a) along transverse axis
c² = a² + b² (note: SUM, unlike ellipse)
Asymptotes: y-k = ±(b/a)(x-h) for horizontal; y-k = ±(a/b)(x-h) for vertical
Eccentricity: e = c/a > 1

examples.problem: For (x+2)²/16 - (y-1)²/9 = 1, find center, vertices, foci, asymptotes, and eccentricity.
examples.solution: Center: (-2,1). a²=16→a=4, b²=9→b=3. Horizontal transverse axis. Vertices: (-2±4,1) = (-6,1) and (2,1). c²=16+9=25→c=5. Foci: (-2±5,1) = (-7,1) and (3,1). Asymptotes: y-1 = ±(3/4)(x+2), i.e., y = (3/4)x + 5/2 and y = -(3/4)x - 1/2. Eccentricity: e = 5/4 = 1.25.

examples.problem: Write the equation of a hyperbola with vertices at (0,±3) and asymptotes y = ±(3/5)x.
examples.solution: Vertical transverse, center (0,0), a=3 (vertices). Asymptotes: y = ±(a/b)x = ±(3/b)x = ±(3/5)x → b=5. Equation: y²/9 - x²/25 = 1.

problems.problem: Identify the conic and find all features: 9x²+4y²-36x+8y-104=0.
Write the equation of a parabola with vertex at (-1, 4) and focus at (-1, 2).
For x²/4 - y²/12 = 1, find foci, asymptotes, and eccentricity.

scaffold.title: Parametric Equations
scaffold.content: Parametric equations define x and y separately as functions of a parameter t: x = f(t), y = g(t). This allows representation of curves that aren't functions, and encodes motion/direction.
keyPoints: Parametric form: x = f(t), y = g(t) for t in some interval
Eliminating the parameter: solve one equation for t, substitute into the other
For trig parametrics: use sin²t + cos²t = 1 to eliminate t
Circle: x = r cos t, y = r sin t; Ellipse: x = a cos t, y = b sin t
Line: x = x₀ + at, y = y₀ + bt
Direction of travel: increasing t shows path direction

examples.problem: Eliminate the parameter and identify the curve: x = 3cos(t), y = 2sin(t).
examples.solution: cos(t) = x/3, sin(t) = y/2. Use sin²t + cos²t = 1: (y/2)² + (x/3)² = 1 → x²/9 + y²/4 = 1. This is an ellipse with a=3, b=2.

examples.problem: Eliminate the parameter: x = t + 1, y = t² - 3t.
examples.solution: From x = t+1: t = x-1. Substitute: y = (x-1)² - 3(x-1) = x² - 2x + 1 - 3x + 3 = x² - 5x + 4. Parabola y = x² - 5x + 4.

examples.problem: Write parametric equations for the line segment from (1, 4) to (5, -2).

scaffold.title: Polar Coordinates & Conversions
scaffold.content: Polar coordinates (r, θ) locate points by distance from origin and angle from positive x-axis. Every point has multiple polar representations.
keyPoints: Conversion: x = r cos θ, y = r sin θ
Conversion: r² = x² + y², tan θ = y/x (adjust quadrant)
Multiple representations: (r, θ) = (r, θ + 2nπ) = (-r, θ + π)
r < 0: point in opposite direction of θ
Common polar equations: r = a (circle), θ = α (line through origin), r = a cos θ or r = a sin θ (circles)

examples.problem: Convert (3, 5π/6) from polar to rectangular coordinates.
Convert (-2, 3) from rectangular to polar coordinates.
examples.solution: r = √(4+9) = √13. tan θ = 3/(-2) → reference angle = arctan(3/2) ≈ 56.31°. Point in Q2 → θ = 180° - 56.31° ≈ 123.69° ≈ 2.159 rad. Polar: (√13, arctan(3/(-2)) + π) or equivalently (√13, π - arctan(3/2)).

examples.problem: Convert the rectangular equation x² + y² - 4x = 0 to polar form.
examples.solution: Substitute: r² - 4r cos θ = 0 → r(r - 4cos θ) = 0. Since r = 0 is just the origin (included when θ gives cos θ > 0), we get r = 4cos θ. This is a circle with diameter 4, centered at (2, 0).

scaffold.title: Polar Curves
scaffold.content: Common polar curve families include roses, limaçons, cardioids, and lemniscates. Their shapes are determined by the form of the equation.
keyPoints: Rose: r = a cos(nθ) or r = a sin(nθ). n petals if n odd; 2n petals if n even.
Limaçon: r = a ± b cos θ (or sin θ). Inner loop if a < b; cardioid if a = b; dimpled if b < a < 2b; convex if a ≥ 2b.
Cardioid: r = a(1 ± cos θ) or r = a(1 ± sin θ). Heart-shaped.
Lemniscate: r² = a² cos(2θ) or r² = a² sin(2θ). Figure-8 shape.
Circle: r = a, r = a cos θ, r = a sin θ.
Symmetry tests: replace θ with -θ (x-axis), replace θ with π-θ (y-axis), replace r with -r (origin)

problems.problem: Convert the polar equation r = 6sin θ to rectangular form and identify the curve.
hints: Multiply both sides by r: r² = 6r sin θ
problems.answer: x² + (y-3)² = 9. Circle centered at (0, 3) with radius 3.

problems.problem: Describe the polar curve r = 2 + 3cos θ. What type is it? Any special features?
hints: Form r = a + b cos θ with a=2, b=3
Since a < b (2 < 3), limaçon with inner loop
problems.answer: Limaçon with inner loop (a < b). The curve has an inner loop when cos θ < -2/3. Max r = 5 (at θ = 0). Symmetric about x-axis.

problems.problem: Find the equation of a parabola with focus (4, -1) and directrix x = -2. Identify vertex and axis of symmetry.
problems.answer: Horizontal axis. Vertex: midpoint of focus and directrix point → ((4+(-2))/2, -1) = (1, -1). p = 4-1 = 3. Equation: (y+1)² = 12(x-1). Axis: y = -1.

problems.problem: For 9x² + 25y² = 225, find center, vertices, foci, and eccentricity.
problems.answer: Divide by 225: x²/25 + y²/9 = 1. Center (0,0). a=5, b=3 (horizontal major). Vertices: (±5, 0). Co-vertices: (0, ±3). c²=25-9=16→c=4. Foci: (±4, 0). e = 4/5 = 0.8.

problems.problem: For y²/9 - x²/16 = 1, find vertices, foci, asymptotes.
problems.answer: Vertical transverse. a²=9→a=3, b²=16→b=4. Vertices: (0, ±3). c²=9+16=25→c=5. Foci: (0, ±5). Asymptotes: y = ±(3/4)x.
cos(t) = (x-1)/4, sin(t) = (y+2)/4. sin²t + cos²t = 1: ((x-1)/4)² + ((y+2)/4)² = 1 → (x-1)² + (y+2)² = 16. Circle centered at (1, -2) with radius 4.

problems.problem: Convert the rectangular equation x² + y² = 6x to polar form.
problems.answer: r² = 6r cos θ → r = 6cos θ. Circle with diameter 6, centered at (3, 0).

problems.problem: For the polar curve r = 4cos(3θ), identify the type of curve and find the number of petals.
problems.answer: Rose curve with n = 3 (odd). Number of petals = 3. Each petal has length 4. Petals at θ = 0, 2π/3, 4π/3.

answerKeys.para-standard: V(3,-1), F(3,-3), dir y=1, axis x=3. Opens down.
